en:
# Institutional Governance

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority, as Hong Kong’s central banking institution, fully understands the importance of good governance in maintaining public trust and confidence in its fulfillment of statutory duties, and remains dedicated to upholding high standards of institutional governance.

To fulfill the commitment to good corporate governance, Hong Kong Monetary Authority:

- Established a clear institutional governance framework;
- Maintained high accountability and transparency, and maintained close contact with all stakeholders; and
- Implemented sound and robust monitoring measures to manage risks and ensure that the conduct and daily operations of all levels of staff comply with specified standards.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s governance framework encompasses several key components, including the statutory advisory committees that provide advice and guidance, accountability and transparency, as well as internal monitoring and external audit.

# Hong Kong Monetary Authority and Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is part of the Government of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China, but it can employ staff under terms of employment different from those of civil servants to attract individuals with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. The HKMA's Chief Executive and its staff are all public officers. The HKMA's day-to-day operations are highly autonomous within the statutory powers conferred upon or delegated to the Financial Secretary.

The Financial Secretary is responsible for determining Hong Kong's monetary policy objectives and monetary system. In a letter dated June 25, 2003, the Financial Secretary outlined that monetary stability should be maintained through the currency board system, keeping the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate at approximately 7.80 HKD per 1 USD. The Commissioner of Financial Services is responsible for achieving these monetary policy objectives, including determining relevant strategies, tools, and methods of implementation, and for maintaining the stability and soundness of Hong Kong’s monetary system.

The Financial Secretary, with the assistance of the Secretary for Financial Services and the Treasury, is responsible for maintaining the stability and soundness of the financial system in Hong Kong, as well as upholding Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre through policy. To implement these policies, the duties of the Commissioner of Financial Management include:

Promote the overall stability and effective functioning of the banking system; cooperate with related bodies to develop the debt market; handle matters relating to the issuance and circulation of legal tender banknotes and coins; promote the safety and efficiency of financial infrastructure through the development of payment, settlement, and clearing systems, and, where appropriate, be responsible for operating such systems; and cooperate with associated entities to enhance confidence in Hong Kong’s monetary and financial systems, and implement appropriate market development measures to assist in strengthening Hong Kong’s international competitiveness in financial services.

The Exchange Fund is controlled by the Financial Secretary. The Financial Controller must exercise the delegated authority from the Financial Secretary and be responsible to the Financial Secretary for the management and investment of the Exchange Fund.

# Advisory Committee and Management Team

# Consultative Committee

The advisory committee provides opinions and guidance on the main areas of work of the Monetary Authority.

The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee was established under the Exchange Fund Ordinance to advise the Financial Secretary on matters relating to the exercise of control over the Exchange Fund. The Financial Secretary is the ex-officio chairman of the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and other members (including the Commissioner for Financial Management) are appointed by the Financial Secretary in their individual capacity, under the authority of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. Members are appointed based on their respective professional knowledge and experience, which greatly benefits the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee. The Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has five specialized committees under it, responsible for monitoring the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority in specific areas and providing advice, and reporting to and making recommendations to the Financial Secretary through the Advisory Committee. Details regarding the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee and its five specialized committees can be found on pages 53 to 63.

The Banking Advisory Committee and the Deposit-Taking Companies Advisory Committee provide advice to the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region on matters related to the Banking Ordinance, particularly concerning banks, deposit-taking companies, and restricted license banks operating banking business or deposit-taking business (as the case may be). Both committees are chaired by the Financial Secretary, with members including the Financial Management Commissioner and other persons appointed by the Financial Secretary upon authorization from the Chief Executive. For details on the Banking Advisory Committee and the Deposit-Taking Companies Advisory Committee, please refer to pages 64 to 65.

# Management Team

The Executive Committee consists of the Governor, Deputy Governors, and other senior officials of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), with the Governor serving as Chairman. The Committee meets regularly to report to the Governor on the progress of major work within the HKMA’s departments and to provide advice to the Governor on policy matters related to the HKMA's operations. Please refer to pages 66 to 67 for the list of Executive Committee members.

# Accountability and Transparency

The Financial Supervisory Commission has consistently maintained a high degree of autonomy in its operational practices and the methods employed to achieve government policy objectives, while also being supported by high accountability and transparency.

The Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is appointed by the Financial Secretary, and therefore the HKMA is accountable to the public through the Financial Secretary. Additionally, since the HKMA's powers are established by laws enacted by the Legislative Council, the HKMA is also accountable to the public through the Legislative Council. The HKMA also recognizes its broader responsibilities, including promoting public understanding of its role and objectives, and closely monitoring issues of concern to the public. In carrying out its daily operations and maintaining extensive engagement with society, the HKMA adheres to a policy of striving to enhance transparency and maintain openness. This policy has two main objectives:

- To the extent permitted by legal restrictions regarding market sensitivity, trade secrets, and the disclosure of confidential information, strive to ensure that the financial industry and the public are fully informed about the work of the HKMA; and
- Ensure that the HKMA keeps abreast of public sentiment and responds appropriately to public opinion.

# Communicating with the Public

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is committed to promoting the stability of the monetary and banking systems, effectively managing official reserves, and developing and supervising a robust and diversified financial infrastructure, thereby consolidating Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre and driving economic development in Hong Kong.

To effectively perform its duties, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) must gain the trust of the public. Therefore, the HKMA adopts a rigorous approach in fulfilling its responsibility to explain its policies and operations to the public. The HKMA maintains extensive contact with the media and utilizes social media platforms to communicate more effectively with the public in the digital age. The HKMA also makes every effort to address issues of public concern that fall within its responsibilities, particularly by promptly clarifying false information and rumors regarding its policies through both traditional and social media channels.

In addition, the HKMA office has an information center, which is divided into a library and an exhibition hall, and is open to the public for visits and use six days a week. Further information is contained in “Chapter on Institutional Functions (pages 185 to 191).”

# Legislative Council

The relationship between the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Legislative Council is very important for enhancing accountability and transparency. The Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has committed to briefing the Financial Affairs Committee of the Legislative Council three times a year on the Authority's work and policies, and to answer relevant inquiries. The Governor’s regular briefings to the Financial Affairs Committee are published on the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s website.

In addition, representatives of the Monetary Authority occasionally attend meetings of the Legislative Council's Standing Committee and Sub-committee to explain and discuss specific matters, as well as assist members in reviewing draft legislation.

# Information Disclosure

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) is committed to achieving international best practices in transparency, publishing various journals and special publications in both Chinese and English. The bilingual website of the HKMA (www.hkma.gov.hk) not only features dedicated sections on economic research, statistical data, regulatory resources, consumer information, and other topics, but also contains a large number of publications, press releases, speeches, and briefing documents issued by the HKMA.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) regularly reviews whether the disclosure of account information of the Exchange Fund and the Hong Kong Note Issuing Office is sufficient. The HKMA participated in the International Monetary Fund's Central Bank "Special Data Dissemination Standard" programme since 1999. The HKMA also publishes the minutes of meetings of the Monetary Issuing Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, as well as reports on the operation of the Hong Kong Note Issuing Office system. Since 1996, the HKMA website has featured banking supervision policies and guidelines.

# Internal monitoring and external audit

The Monetary Authority adopts a stable and effective monitoring mechanism to ensure adherence to a high standard of employee integrity, prudent risk management, and appropriate checks and balances. Internal and external audit functions provide independent assessments of whether the monitoring mechanism is sufficient and effective.

# Code of Conduct

The Code of Conduct provides guidance on the ethical and legal responsibilities of employees, ensuring that the conduct of all staff at all levels complies with specified standards.

# Internal Monitoring

# Operation Monitoring

As the first line of defense in risk management, all departments and branches are responsible for identifying and assessing risks in their workflows, and implementing appropriate monitoring measures to ensure the smooth operation of the Monetary Authority's daily activities.

# Organizational risk management

Risk management also takes place at the institutional level. The Risk Committee, chaired by the Governor of the Monetary Authority, is one of the cornerstones of the institution's risk management framework.

The Risk Committee reviews and reports on potential and emerging risks identified by various departments, assessing the adequacy of monitoring measures and mitigation strategies, and determines appropriate follow-up actions.

# Internal Audit

The Internal Audit Department of the Monetary Authority independently evaluates whether the governance processes, risk management, and monitoring measures of different departments are adequate and effective, and provides recommendations for improvement.

# External Audit

According to Section 7 of the Foreign Exchange Fund Ordinance, the financial statements of the Foreign Exchange Fund are reviewed by the Audit Department of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region government. The Audit Department does not charge fees for this service. The audited financial statements of the Foreign Exchange Fund are published in the Hong Kong Monetary Authority's Annual Report.

# 經濟及金融環境

香港經濟在2024年錄得溫和增長，主要受惠於貨物出口在外部需求改善及全球科技周期復甦下有所反彈。勞工市場保持穩健，通脹在外圍價格壓力進一步減退下維持溫和。本港股市顯著回升，而物業市場則因市場氣氛在持續高息環境下受壓而大致疲弱。鑑於貿易緊張局勢不斷升級，預計2025年香港經濟將會面對充滿挑戰的外圍環境。然而，中國內地積極推出經濟刺激措施，加上為本地企業提供的多方面支持，應能鞏固營商信心。香港亦會繼續加強國際交往合作，以及深化區域合作。

# 經濟回顧

# 實體經濟活動

香港經濟在2024年溫和增長。實質本地生產總值繼2023年錄得3.2%的增幅後，在2024年按年上升2.5%（表1及圖1）。外圍方面，貨物出口在外部需求改善及全球科技周期復甦的帶動下恢復正增長，成為整體經濟增長的主要動力。服務輸出亦隨着訪港旅遊業的持續復甦，以及跨境金融及集資活動於下半年顯著增加而進一步增長。然而，由於服務輸入在出境旅遊業持續增長下顯著上升，抵銷了服務輸出對整體經濟增長所帶來的正面效應。本地方面，私人消費開支在本地居民的消費模式轉變下有所回軟。相反，物業成交增加以及營商氣氛在貨幣狀況逐步放寬下有所改善，帶動整體投資支出錄得輕微增長。

圖 1 組成部分對實質本地生產總值增長的貢獻
資料來源：政府統計處

表 1 按開支項目計的實質本地生產總值增長（比對上期）
註：經季節性調整的本地固定資本形成總額按季增減幅度不詳。
資料來源：政府統計處

# 通脹及勞工市場

儘管新簽訂私人住宅租金逐步上升，本地成本壓力仍大致受控，加上外圍價格壓力逐步減退，本地通脹在2024年維持溫和（圖2）。2024年全年合計，基本及整體通脹率分別為1.1%及1.7%。

勞工市場在2024年表現穩健，失業率全年在2.9%至3.1%的低位徘徊（圖3）。自第1季起，總就業人數（圖3）逐步上升，勞動人口亦見增加，反映勞工需求與供應大致保持穩定。與此同時，隨着經濟持續增長，名義工資與勞工收入均錄得穩健增長。此外，政府在2024年《施政報告》中宣布進一步優化香港的吸引人才計劃，以紓緩不同行業的人手短缺問題，並透過吸納更多年輕人，為本地人口注入新動力。

圖 2 基本消費物價通脹
資料來源：政府統計處

圖 3 勞工市場狀況
資料來源：政府統計處

# 股市

本港股市隨着9月中以來的大幅反彈，於2024年顯著轉向。具體而言，隨着美國聯邦儲備局（美聯儲）減息及內地推出積極的經濟刺激措施，市場氣氛顯著改善，帶動恒生指數在10月7日升至全年高位，收報23,100點（圖4）。然而，11月初舉行的美國總統選舉觸發市場對全球經濟前景及美聯儲放寬貨幣政策步伐的憂慮，本港股市略為回調。儘管如此，恒生指數於年底收報20,060點，較2023年年底大幅上升17.7%，終結連續四年下挫的走勢。

# 物業市場

住宅物業市場在2024年首三季大致疲軟，但在第4季出現回穩跡象。在2月底及10月中相關政策措施放寬，以及9月開始的減息周期的支持下，全年住宅成交量由2023年43,002宗的歷史低位大幅上升23.5%至2024年的53,099宗。然而，持續高企的按揭利率及一手市場累積的庫存，繼續對樓價構成下調壓力。因此，樓價在2024年按年下跌7.1%，置業負擔能力亦因而稍為改善，雖然仍屬偏緊。非住宅物業市場仍然疲弱。其中，寫字樓的空置率在供應充裕的情況下仍然高企，零售商舖則面對旅客與本地居民消費模式轉變所帶來的挑戰。

圖 4 資產價格
資料來源：差餉物業估價署及香港交易及結算所有限公司

# 經濟前景

# 經濟環境

鑑於貿易緊張局勢不斷升溫，並很可能會對國際貿易與資金流造成干擾，預計香港經濟於2025年將會面對充滿挑戰的外圍環境。然而，各有關當局及銀行業持續提供多方面的支持，應能提升本地企業的抗禦能力。內地積極推出經濟刺激措施，並且在前沿科技領域取得重大突破，亦應能提振營商信心。與此同時，香港會進一步深化區域合作，並加快聯動新興市場。同時，在內地當局的惠港旅遊政策，以及政府致力提振香港旅遊業的支持下，預計訪港旅遊業將會進一步增長。

# 通脹及勞工市場

預期本地通脹於2025年將保持溫和。由於房屋租金上升將逐步傳遞至消費物價，本地成本可能面對輕微的上升壓力。然而，儘管環球經濟前景的不確定性有所增加，但外圍價格壓力應會保持溫和。另一方面，勞工市場或會因貿易緊張局勢升溫而面對挑戰。然而，各項吸引人才計劃應有助繼續建立優質人才庫，為經濟長遠發展提供支持。

# 銀行體系表現

香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健，銀行的資本及流動性均十分充裕。在宏觀經濟環境充滿挑戰下，年內銀行體系面對的信用風險增加，但銀行的整體資產質素維持可控。受惠於來自持有作交易的投資收益與收費及佣金收入上升，零售銀行盈利較2023年有所增長。

# 資產質素

銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率由2023年底的1.57%上升至2024年底的1.96%，逾期及經重組貸款比率於同期由1.24%升至1.55%（圖5）。特定分類貸款比率上升，主要是部分內地房地產發展商以及本地中小型發展商和投資者的貸款評級被下調所導致。然而，中國內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率由2023年底的2.58%，下降至2024年底的2.38%。銀行撥備維持充足。截至2024年底，銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率（即信貸撥備和特定分類貸款比率）約為65%。若將抵押品變現價值從呆壞帳餘額中扣除，經調整的銀行信貸撥備覆蓋率約145%。與此同時，2024年底住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率仍然處於低水平，分別為0.11%及0.35%（圖6）。

圖 5 銀行體系的資產質素
資料來源：金管局

圖 6 住宅按揭貸款及信用卡貸款的拖欠比率
資料來源：金管局

# 盈利走勢

零售銀行在2024年的整體除稅前經營溢利增加8.4%，同期除稅後平均資產回報率則由0.88%上升至0.93%（圖7）。盈利增長主要是由於持有作交易的投資收益（+97.0%）與收費及佣金收入增加（+15.4%），但部分升幅被淨利息收入減少（–5.2%）所抵銷。零售銀行淨息差由2023年的1.67%收窄至 2024 年的 1.52%（圖8）。與此同時，零售銀行成本與收入比率由2023年的38.9%微升至2024年的39.2%（圖9）。

圖 7 零售銀行的表現
資料來源：金管局

圖 8 零售銀行淨息差
資料來源：金管局

圖 9 零售銀行成本與收入比率
資料來源：金管局

# 資產負債表走勢

銀行體系資產負債表在2024年擴大4.3%，主要是因為可轉讓債務工具增加（+13.4%）。由於借貸成本高企，貸款需求受壓，2024年貸款總額減少2.8%。其中在香港使用的貸款與在香港境外使用的貸款分別減少2.1%及5.7%，貿易融資則增加4.6%。中國內地相關貸款於2024年減少8.7%。

在資產負債表的負債方面，存款總額於2024年增加7.1%，相比2023年的增幅為5.1%。由於貸款總額減少而存款總額增加，整體貸存比率由2023底的62.8%降至2024年底的57.0%（圖10）。

# 資本充足水平

銀行體系在2024年資本維持充裕。2024年底本地註冊認可機構的綜合總資本比率為21.8%，相比上一年為21.1%；一級資本比率為19.9%（圖11）。兩者均遠高於相關國際最低要求。《巴塞爾協定三》槓桿比率於2024 年底為 8.0%（圖12）。

圖 10 銀行體系的貸款及存款
資料來源：金管局

圖 11 本地註冊認可機構的綜合資本比率
資料來源：金管局

圖 12 本地註冊認可機構的綜合槓桿比率
資料來源：金管局

# 流動性狀況

銀行體系的流動性狀況維持穩健。第1類機構的季度平均流動性覆蓋比率在2024年第4季為178.4%，第2類機構的季度平均流動性維持比率為67.0%（圖13）。銀行體系的主要資金來源仍然是客戶存款。於2024年底，第1類機構的穩定資金淨額比率及第2A類機構的核心資金比率分別為143.4%及186.7%（圖14）。以上所有四個比率均遠高於法定最低要求。

圖 13 指定認可機構的流動性比率
資料來源：金管局

圖 14 指定認可機構的資金比率
資料來源：金管局

en:
# Economic and Financial Landscape

Hong Kong's economy recorded moderate growth in 2024, mainly benefiting from a rebound in goods exports amid improved external demand and the recovery of the global technology cycle. The labor market remained robust, and inflation stayed moderate as external price pressures further eased. The local stock market showed a significant recovery, while the property market remained generally weak due to a subdued market sentiment under the continued high-interest rate environment. Given the escalating trade tensions, Hong Kong's economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, the mainland China's proactive implementation of economic stimulus measures, combined with multifaceted support provided to local businesses, should help reinforce business confidence. Hong Kong will also continue to enhance international cooperation and deepen regional collaboration.

# Economic Review

# Real Economic Activities

Hong Kong's economy experienced moderate growth in 2024. The real local gross domestic product (GDP) rose by 2.5% year-on-year in 2024, following a 3.2% increase in 2023 (Table 1 and Figure 1). Externally, goods exports returned to positive growth, driven by improved external demand and the recovery of the global technology cycle, becoming a major driver of overall economic growth. Service exports also increased further, supported by the continued recovery of the tourism sector and a significant rise in cross-border financial and fundraising activities in the second half of the year. However, the significant increase in service imports, driven by the sustained growth in outbound tourism, offset the positive effects of service exports on overall economic growth. Domestically, private consumption expenditure softened slightly due to changes in the consumption patterns of local residents. In contrast, the increase in property transactions and an improvement in the business climate, amid gradually easing monetary conditions, led to a mild increase in overall investment expenditure.

Figure 1 Contribution of constituent parts to real GDP growth
Source: Census and Statistics Department

Table 1: Real Gross Domestic Product Growth by Expenditure Category (Compared to the Previous Period)  
Note: The quarterly change in seasonally adjusted local gross fixed capital formation is not available.  
Source: Government Statistics Department

# Inflation and the Labor Market

Although private residential rental prices continued to rise gradually, local cost pressures remained largely under control, along with decreasing external price pressures, keeping local inflation moderate in 2024 (Figure 2). For the whole year of 2024, the core and overall inflation rates were 1.1% and 1.7%, respectively.

The labor market remained robust in 2024, with the unemployment rate hovering at a low range between 2.9% and 3.1% throughout the year (Figure 3). Starting from the first quarter, total employment numbers (Figure 3) gradually increased, and the labor force also saw an increase, reflecting a broadly stable balance between labor demand and supply. At the same time, with continued economic growth, both nominal wages and labor income recorded steady growth. Furthermore, the government announced further optimization of Hong Kong’s talent attraction program in the 2024 Policy Address to alleviate labor shortages across different industries and inject new momentum into the local population by attracting more young people.

Figure 2: Basic Consumer Price Inflation. Data Source: Government Statistics Department.

Figure 3 Labor Market Conditions
Data Source: Statistics Department

# Stock Market

The Hong Kong stock market significantly turned around in 2024 following a sharp rebound since mid-September. Specifically, with the Federal Reserve (Fed) cutting interest rates and mainland China implementing proactive economic stimulus measures, market sentiment improved substantially, driving the Hang Seng Index to its annual high on October 7, closing at 23,100 points (Figure 4). However, the U.S. presidential election held in early November triggered market concerns about the global economic outlook and the pace of the Fed's monetary policy easing, leading to a slight retreat in the Hong Kong stock market. Despite this, the Hang Seng Index closed at 20,060 points by year-end, a significant 17.7% increase from the end of 2023, ending a four-year consecutive decline trend.

# Real Estate Market

The residential property market remained generally weak during the first three quarters of 2024 but showed signs of stabilization in the fourth quarter. Supported by the relaxation of relevant policy measures in late February and mid-October, as well as the interest rate cut cycle initiated in September, the annual residential transaction volume rose sharply by 23.5% from the historical low of 43,002 units in 2023 to 53,099 units in 2024. However, persistently high mortgage interest rates and accumulated inventory in the new property market continued to exert downward pressure on property prices. As a result, property prices fell by 7.1% year-on-year in 2024, with housing affordability slightly improving although it remained relatively tight. The non-residential property market remained weak, with office vacancy rates remaining high despite ample supply, while retail properties faced challenges stemming from shifting consumption patterns among both tourists and local residents.

Figure 4: Asset Prices  
Source: Rating and Valuation Department and Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited

# Economic Prospects

#EconomicEnvironment

Given the escalating trade tensions and the likely disruption to international trade and capital flows, Hong Kong's economy is expected to face a challenging external environment in 2025. However, continued multifaceted support from relevant authorities and the banking sector should enhance the resilience of local businesses. Proactive economic stimulus measures from China and significant breakthroughs in frontier technologies should also boost business confidence. At the same time, Hong Kong will further deepen regional cooperation and accelerate linkages with emerging markets. Furthermore, with favorable tourism policies from authorities in China and the government’s commitment to supporting the tourism industry, visitor numbers to Hong Kong are expected to grow further.

# Inflation and the Labor Market

Inflation is expected to remain moderate in 2025. As rising housing rents gradually pass through to consumer prices, local costs may face slight upward pressure. However, despite the increased uncertainty in the global economic outlook, external price pressures should remain moderate. On the other hand, the labor market may face challenges due to the intensifying trade tensions. Nevertheless, various talent attraction programs should help in continuing to build a high-quality talent pool, supporting the economy's long-term development.

# Banking system performance

The Hong Kong banking system remained robust in 2024, with banks maintaining ample capital and liquidity. Amid a challenging macroeconomic environment, the banking system faced increased credit risk during the year, but the overall quality of bank assets remained manageable. Benefiting from higher investment income from trading activities and increased fee and commission income, retail bank profits rose compared to 2023.

# Asset Quality

The specific classification loan ratio of the banking system rose from 1.57% at the end of 2023 to 1.96% at the end of 2024, while the ratio of overdue and restructured loans increased from 1.24% to 1.55% during the same period (Figure 5). This increase in the specific classification loan ratio was primarily driven by downgrades in loan ratings for certain mainland Chinese real estate developers, as well as local small and medium-sized developers and investors. However, the specific classification loan ratio for mainland-related loans decreased from 2.58% at the end of 2023 to 2.38% at the end of 2024. Bank provisions remained adequate, with the bank credit provision coverage ratio (i.e., the ratio of credit provisions to specific classification loan ratios) standing at approximately 65% as of the end of 2024. When the liquidation value of collateral is deducted from the non-performing loan balance, the adjusted bank credit provision coverage ratio reached approximately 145%. Meanwhile, delinquency rates for residential mortgage loans and credit card loans remained at low levels at the end of 2024, at 0.11% and 0.35%, respectively (Figure 6).

Figure 5 Asset Quality of the Banking System
Data Source: Monetary Authority

Figure 6 Mortgage and Credit Card Loan Delinquency Rates
Data source: Financial Supervisory Commission

# Profitability Trends

Retail banking’s overall pre-tax operating profit increased by 8.4% in 2024, while the average return on assets after tax rose from 0.88% to 0.93% during the same period (Figure 7). Profit growth was primarily driven by gains from investments held for trading (+97.0%) and an increase in fee and commission income (+15.4%), although part of the growth was offset by a decline in net interest income (–5.2%). The net interest margin of retail banking narrowed from 1.67% in 2023 to 1.52% in 2024 (Figure 8). At the same time, the cost-to-income ratio of retail banking rose slightly from 38.9% in 2023 to 39.2% in 2024 (Figure 9).  
Retail banking’s overall pre-tax operating profit increased by 8.4% in 2024, while the average return on assets after tax rose from 0.88% to 0.93% during the same period (Figure 7). Profit growth was primarily driven by gains from investments held for trading (+97.0%) and an increase in fee and commission income (+15.4%), although part of the growth was offset by a decline in net interest income (–5.2%). The net interest margin of retail banking narrowed from 1.67% in 2023 to 1.52% in 2024 (Figure 8). At the same time, the cost-to-income ratio of retail banking rose slightly from 38.9% in 2023 to 39.2% in 2024 (Figure 9).

Figure 7: Performance of Retail Banking. Data Source: Monetary Authority.

Figure 8 Retail Banking Net Interest Margin
Data source: Financial Supervisory Authority

Figure 9 Retail banking cost and revenue ratio
Data source: Financial Supervisory Authority

# Balance sheet trends

The banking system's balance sheet expanded by 4.3% in 2024, mainly due to an increase in transferable debt instruments (+13.4%). Due to high lending costs, loan demand was suppressed, resulting in a 2.8% decrease in total loans in 2024. Among these, loans used in Hong Kong decreased by 2.1%, while loans used outside Hong Kong decreased by 5.7%, and trade financing increased by 4.6%. Loans related to mainland China decreased by 8.7% in 2024.

In the liabilities section of the balance sheet, total deposits increased by 7.1% in 2024, compared to 5.1% in 2023. With total loans decreasing and deposits increasing, the overall loan-to-deposit ratio fell from 62.8% at the end of 2023 to 57.0% at the end of 2024 (Figure 10).

# Capital Adequacy Level

The banking system maintained ample capital adequacy in 2024. The comprehensive capital ratio of locally registered and authorized institutions at the end of 2024 was 21.8%, compared to 21.1% in the previous year; the Tier 1 capital ratio was 19.9% (Figure 11). Both are significantly higher than the relevant international minimum requirements. The Basel III leverage ratio at the end of 2024 was 8.0% (Figure 12).

Figure 10 Loan and Deposit in the Banking System  
Data Source: Monetary Authority

Figure 11 Comprehensive Capital Ratio of Local Registered and Recognized Institutions  
Data Source: Monetary Authority

Figure 12 Comprehensive leverage ratio of locally registered authorized institutions. Data source: Hong Kong Monetary Authority.

# Liquidity Status

The liquidity position of the banking system remains robust. The quarterly average liquidity coverage ratio for Category 1 institutions was 178.4% in the fourth quarter of 2024, while the quarterly average liquidity maintenance ratio for Category 2 institutions was 67.0% (Figure 13). The main source of funds for the banking system remains customer deposits. At the end of 2024, the net stable funding ratio for Category 1 institutions and the core funding ratio for Category 2A institutions were 143.4% and 186.7%, respectively (Figure 14). All four ratios are significantly above the statutory minimum requirements.

Figure 13 specifies the liquidity ratios of approved institutions.
Data source: Financial Supervisory Agency

Figure 14 specifies the capital adequacy ratio of authorized institutions.
Data source: Financial Supervisory Agency

zh:
# 貨幣穩定

儘管美國貨幣政策走向、環球增長前景及地緣政治局勢緊張存在不明朗因素港元外匯及貨幣市場繼續保持暢順有序。港元匯率在2024年首四個月回軟，然後在年內其餘時間轉強。在聯繫匯率制度下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率的走勢，同時亦受本地供求情況影響。作為香港貨幣及金融穩定的基石，聯繫匯率制度一直展現強大抵禦外來衝擊的能力。

# 目標

香港貨幣政策的主要目標是維持貨幣穩定，即確保港元匯價穩定，使港元在外匯市場兌美元的匯率保持在7.75至7.85港元兌1美元的區間內。該貨幣體制主要採用貨幣發行局制度，規定由外匯基金所持的美元儲備向貨幣基礎提供最少百分之百的支持；貨幣基礎若有變動，美元儲備亦必須作出相應增減，與貨幣基礎的變動百分之百配合。

貨幣基礎（表1）包括：

- 負債證明書（為三間發鈔銀行發行的銀行紙幣提供十足支持）；
- 政府發行的流通紙幣及硬幣；
- 設於金管局的結算戶口結餘總額（即總結餘）；及
- 金管局代表政府發行的外匯基金票據及債券。

表1 貨幣基礎

金管局透過自動利率調節機制及履行兌換保證的堅決承諾來維持港元匯率的穩定。當強方（或弱方）兌換保證被觸發，金管局會應銀行要求，按每美元兌7.75港元向銀行沽出港元、買入美元（或按7.85港元買入港元、沽出美元），使總結餘增加（或減少），令港元利率下跌（或上升），從而促使港元匯率回復到7.75至7.85的兌換範圍。

# 2024年回顧

# 匯率穩定

在2024年首四個月，港元隨着流動性回軟而稍為轉弱。在4月下旬至5月中期間，主要在股息相關資金需求及股票市場交投活躍的支持下，港元匯率轉強。在8月初，由於市場一度憂慮美國經濟可能出現衰退，以及預期美國聯邦儲備局將以更快及更大幅度減息，觸發套息交易平倉及港元短倉平倉，使港元轉強至兌換保證範圍的強方。港元在9月下旬進一步走強，受惠於內地公布一系列經濟刺激措施後，本港股市交投急增。港元其後於11月初稍為轉弱，部分由於本港股市的升幅有所回落，部分則由於其時美國經濟表現強勁，給予聯邦公開市場委員會空間謹慎地調低聯邦基金利率所致。其後港元在年底季節性資金需求帶動下回升。整體而言，港元外匯市場在2024年全年繼續運作正常（圖1）。

圖 1 2024年市場匯率

由於年內並無觸發兌換保證，總結餘變動不大，維持在447億港元左右。與此同時，未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由12,455億港元，稍增至13,839億港元。因此，總結餘與未償還外匯基金票據及債券總額由2023 年底的 12,904 億港元，增加至 2024 年底的 14,287億港元（圖2）。整體貨幣基礎仍然由外匯儲備提供十足支持。

圖 2 2024年總結餘（進行貼現窗活動前）及未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣市場

在聯繫匯率制度（聯匯制度）下，香港銀行同業拆息大致跟隨美元利率走勢，當中短期拆息亦受本地供求情況影響。隨着市場對美國政策利率下調的預期逐漸升溫，香港銀行同業拆息在2024年首八個月大致回軟（圖3）。在季末季節性資金需求及股市交投活躍的推動下，香港銀行同業拆息於9月下旬收緊，隔夜拆息於季末更一度升至6厘以上。其後香港銀行同業拆息大致穩定，至年底前因流動性相對減少而上升。全年計，隔夜、一個月及三個月香港銀行同業拆息分別下跌45、69及78基點至年底時的5.65厘、4.58厘及4.37厘。

因應美國聯邦基金利率目標區間下調，基本利率下調三次，合共一個百分點（即100基點），由5.75厘下跌至4.75厘（圖3）。在零售層面，隨着美國下調政策利率，多間銀行在9月中調低最優惠貸款利率25基點，並在11月初及12月下旬分別再調低25基點及12.5基點。在此情況下，新造按揭貸款平均利率亦由2023年的4.13厘下跌至2024年12月的3.59厘。整體而言，香港貨幣市場繼續正常運作。貼現窗借貸由2023年的388億港元增至2024年的500億港元；貼現窗的使用情況未見異常。

圖 3 2024年香港銀行同業拆息

# 聯繫匯率制度

自1983年以來，聯匯制度一直是香港金融體系的重要支柱，展現強大應對挑戰的能力。儘管美國政策利率走向存在不確定因素，以及地緣經濟碎片化，港元外匯及貨幣市場維持有序運作，反映聯匯制度穩健有效。政府亦堅決維持聯匯制度。國際貨幣基金組織（基金組織）在《2024年對外部門報告》一再重申香港擁有具透明度的規則、龐大的財政及外匯儲備、穩健的金融規管與監管、靈活的經濟，以及審慎的財政架構，確保聯匯制度具公信力。

穩健的銀行體系對聯匯制度的正常運作具關鍵作用。香港銀行體系繼續運作暢順，流動性及資本狀況以國際標準而言均非常充裕。為確保銀行體系具備抵禦衝擊的能力，金管局一直密切監察銀行的信用、流動性與利率風險管理，以及壓力測試結果，並維持對銀行貸款的監管。

為提高貨幣發行局帳目的透明度，自1998年10月起，外匯基金已有部分資產被指定用作支持貨幣基礎。支持比率（即支持資產相對貨幣基礎的比率）由2023年底的110.73%上升至2024年9月10日的112.65%高位，超出112.5%的觸發上限（圖4），當中主要來自投資的利息及投資按市價重估。按照外匯基金諮詢委員會批准的安排，從支持組合轉撥資產至投資組合，令支持比率於9月11日降至110.08%左右。其後支持比率大致保持穩定，於12月31日收報109.56%。在聯匯制度下，雖然已指定某些外匯基金資產作為支持組合，但外匯基金的全部資產均可用作支持港元匯率。外匯基金的龐大財政資源，加上香港穩健的銀行體系，為保障香港的貨幣及金融穩定提供強而有力的後盾。

圖 4 2024年支持比率每日變動

# 貨幣發行委員會

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的貨幣發行委員會負責監察及探討與香港貨幣及金融穩定有關的課題。在2024年，貨幣發行委員會探討的課題包括香港銀行業對非銀行金融機構的風險承擔，以及主要先進經濟體的最新貨幣政策實施框架。貨幣發行委員會會議紀錄及金管局向其呈交的貨幣發行局制度運作報告，均載於金管局網站。

# 紙幣及硬幣

圖 5 2024年底按發鈔銀行分析的銀行紙幣流通金額

圖 6 2024年底流通銀行紙幣分布情況

圖 7 2024年底銀行紙幣流通金額

圖 8 2024年底政府發行紙幣及硬幣流通金額

圖 9 2024年底政府發行流通紙幣及硬幣分析

# 香港鈔票

年內金管局舉辦14場有關香港鈔票設計及防偽特徵的講座，吸引超過2,600人參加，包括銀行櫃位職員、零售店舖收銀員及學生，有助提高他們鑑別鈔票的知識及技巧。

# 硬幣收集計劃

硬幣收集計劃繼續受到市民歡迎。有關計劃詳情載於《二零二四年可持續發展報告》之「可持續發展的金管局」一章。

# 美元流動資金安排

金管局推出美元流動資金安排的優化措施，包括將交收周期由T+1縮短至T+0，於5月24日生效。此項恆常流動資金安排可在持牌銀行有需要時為其提供備用流動性，尤其是在5月28日美國開始實施交收周期縮短至T+1的情況下。

# 外匯基金票據及債券

外匯基金票據及債券計劃繼續暢順運作。截至2024年底，未償還外匯基金票據及債券名義總值約為13,068億港元（表2）。

表 2 未償還外匯基金票據及債券

# 貨幣研究

在2024年，金融學院轄下負責研究工作的香港貨幣及金融研究中心（研究中心）發表15份對香港以至區內具戰略重要性的貨幣與金融研究議題的研究論文，並透過五期開放取用電子期刊與全球讀者分享研究成果。研究中心亦出版兩份《Insights from MonetaryResearch》，就其近期發表的研究論文為公眾提供高層次非技術性的概要。

除研究工作外，研究中心舉辦一系列知識交流活動，促進與不同參與者的聯繫。年內舉辦31場以本地參與者為對象的研討會或網上研討會，探討重要貨幣及金融研究議題。在國際層面，金融學院與研究中心聯同學術機構、各國央行及國際金融機構舉辦四次國際會議及五次研討會或圓桌會議，促進就廣泛經濟及金融事務的對話與交流。

這些國際活動包括：

4月11日

與金管局及香港科技大學合辦

6月6至7日 「NBER東亞經濟研討會2024」

與美國全國經濟研究所、國際結算銀行及香港科技大學商學院合辦

7月15至16日

與基金組織、國際結算銀行及東盟與中日韓宏觀經濟研究辦公室合辦

10月14至15日

第14屆年度中國經濟國際研討會—「中國及全球貿易結構的演變：挑戰與機遇」

# Currency Stability

Despite uncertainties surrounding the direction of US monetary policy, the global growth outlook, and geopolitical tensions, the Hong Kong dollar foreign exchange and money market continued to function smoothly and orderly. The Hong Kong dollar exchange rate softened in the first four months of 2024, then strengthened for the remainder of the year. Under the linked exchange rate system, the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (HIBOR) has largely followed the trend of US interest rates, while also being affected by local supply and demand. As the cornerstone of monetary and financial stability in Hong Kong, the linked exchange rate system has consistently demonstrated a strong ability to withstand external shocks.

# objective

The main objective of Hong Kong’s monetary policy is to maintain monetary stability, which means ensuring the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate, keeping the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar against the US dollar within the range of HK$7.75 to HK$7.85 per US dollar. This monetary system primarily employs a currency issuance bureau system, stipulating that the US dollar reserves held by the Exchange Fund must provide at least 100% support for the monetary base; if the monetary base changes, the US dollar reserves must also be adjusted accordingly, fully matching the changes in the monetary base.

The monetary base (Table 1) includes:

- Certificates of indebtedness (issued to provide full backing for banknotes of the three note-issuing banks);
- Government-issued currency notes and coins in circulation;
- The aggregate balances of clearing accounts maintained with the HKMA (i.e. the total balance); and
- Exchange Fund bills and bonds issued by the HKMA on behalf of the Government.

Table 1: Monetary Base

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains the stability of the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate through the automatic interest rate adjustment mechanism and its firm commitment to honoring exchange rate guarantees. When a strong (or weak) exchange rate guarantee is triggered, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, upon request from banks, will sell Hong Kong dollars and buy US dollars from banks at a rate of HK$7.75 per US dollar (or buy Hong Kong dollars and sell US dollars at a rate of HK$7.85), increasing (or decreasing) the aggregate balance, thereby lowering (or raising) Hong Kong dollar interest rates, and thus bringing the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate back within the HK$7.75-7.85 exchange rate range.

# 2024 Retrospective

# Exchange Rate Stability

In the first four months of 2024, the Hong Kong dollar slightly weakened as liquidity eased. From late April to mid-May, the Hong Kong dollar strengthened, mainly supported by dividend-related funding demand and active stock market trading. In early August, concerns over a potential U.S. economic downturn and expectations of a faster and more significant rate cut by the Federal Reserve triggered unwind of carry trades and short positions in the Hong Kong dollar, pushing the currency to the strong side of the exchange rate guarantee range. The Hong Kong dollar further strengthened in late September, benefiting from increased trading activity in the local stock market following the announcement of a series of economic stimulus measures by mainland China. The Hong Kong dollar then slightly weakened in early November, partly due to a decline in local stock market gains, and partly due to strong U.S. economic performance, which provided the Federal Open Market Committee with room to cautiously lower the federal funds rate. Subsequently, the Hong Kong dollar rebounded in the fourth quarter, driven by seasonal funding demand. Overall, the foreign exchange market for the Hong Kong dollar continued to operate normally throughout 2024 (Figure 1).

Figure 1: 2024 Market Exchange Rate

Due to no activation of the exchange guarantee within the year, the aggregate balance remained relatively stable, around 447 billion HK$. At the same time, the total amount of outstanding Exchange Fund bills and bonds increased slightly from 12,455 billion HK$ to 13,839 billion HK$. Consequently, the aggregate balance and the total amount of outstanding Exchange Fund bills and bonds increased from 1,290.4 billion HK$ at the end of 2023 to 14,287 billion HK$ at the end of 2024 (Figure 2). The overall monetary base remains fully backed by foreign exchange reserves.

Figure 2 2024 Year-End Surplus (Before Conducting Discount Window Activities) and Unrepaid Foreign Exchange Fund Bills and Bonds

# Currency Market

Under the linked exchange rate system, the Hong Kong Interbank Offered Rate (HIBOR) generally follows US dollar interest rate trends, with short-term rates also influenced by local supply and demand. As market expectations of a US policy rate cut gradually increased, HIBOR generally softened during the first eight months of 2024 (Figure 3). Driven by end-of-quarter seasonal funding needs and active stock market trading, HIBOR tightened in late September, with the overnight rate briefly rising above 6% at the end of the quarter. Subsequently, HIBOR remained largely stable, and rose before the end of the year due to relatively reduced liquidity. For the year, overnight, one-month, and three-month HIBOR rates fell by 45, 69, and 78 basis points respectively, to 5.65%, 4.58%, and 4.37% at year-end.

In response to the reduction in the target range of the U.S. federal funds rate, the basic interest rate was cut three times, totaling one percentage point (i.e., 100 basis points), decreasing from 5.75 to 4.75 (Figure 3). At the retail level, following the U.S. reduction in policy rates, several banks lowered their prime lending rates by 25 basis points in mid-September, and by an additional 25 basis points in early November and 12.5 basis points in late December. Under these circumstances, the average interest rate for new mortgage loans also fell from 4.13 in 2023 to 3.59 in December 2024. Overall, the Hong Kong money market continued to operate normally. Discount window lending increased from HKD 388 billion in 2023 to HKD 500 billion in 2024; the use of the discount window showed no abnormalities.

Figure 3: Hong Kong Interbank Offer Rate (HIBOR) in 2024

# Linked Exchange Rate System

Since 1983, the Linked Exchange Rate System has been a crucial pillar of Hong Kong’s financial system, demonstrating strong resilience in the face of challenges. Despite uncertainties regarding U.S. policy interest rates and geopolitical and economic fragmentation, the Hong Kong dollar’s foreign exchange and money markets have maintained orderly operations, reflecting the system’s robustness and effectiveness. The government remains firmly committed to maintaining the Linked Exchange Rate System. The International Monetary Fund (IMF) reiterated in its 2024 External Sector Report that Hong Kong possesses transparent rules, substantial fiscal and foreign exchange reserves, robust financial regulation and supervision, a flexible economy, and a prudent fiscal framework, ensuring the credibility of the Linked Exchange Rate System.

A sound banking system plays a crucial role in the proper functioning of the exchange rate regime. The Hong Kong banking system continues to operate smoothly, with liquidity and capital positions that are highly adequate by international standards. To ensure the banking system has the capacity to withstand shocks, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority has been closely monitoring banks' credit, liquidity, and interest rate risk management, as well as the results of stress tests, and maintaining regulation over bank lending.

To enhance the transparency of the currency board’s accounts, a portion of the Exchange Fund’s assets has been designated as support for the monetary base since October 1998. The support ratio (i.e., the ratio of support assets to the monetary base) increased from 110.73% at the end of 2023 to a high of 112.65% as of September 10, 2024, exceeding the trigger limit of 112.5% (Figure 4), mainly due to interest income from investments and the revaluation of investments at market prices. Following an arrangement approved by the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, assets were transferred from the support portfolio to the investment portfolio, bringing the support ratio down to approximately 110.08% on September 11. Subsequently, the support ratio remained relatively stable, closing at 109.56% on December 31. Under the linked exchange rate system, although certain Exchange Fund assets have been designated as the support portfolio, the Exchange Fund’s entire assets can be used to support the Hong Kong dollar exchange rate. The Exchange Fund’s substantial financial resources, coupled with Hong Kong’s sound banking system, provide a strong and robust backing for safeguarding Hong Kong’s monetary and financial stability.

Figure 4 2024 support ratio varies daily.

# Monetary Issuance Committee

The Currency Board, which is under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, is responsible for monitoring and examining issues related to Hong Kong's monetary and financial stability. In 2024, topics discussed by the Currency Board included the risk exposure of Hong Kong's banking sector to non-banking financial institutions, as well as the latest monetary policy implementation frameworks in major advanced economies. Meeting minutes of the Currency Board and the reports on the operation of the Currency Board submitted by the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) are available on the HKMA website.

# Banknotes and coins

Figure 5: Banknote Circulation Amount at the End of 2024 Based on Analysis by the Issuing Bank

Figure 6: Distribution of circulating banknotes at the end of 2024.

Figure 7 2024 year-end bank banknote circulation amount

Figure 8: Amount of paper money and coins in circulation issued by the government as of the end of 2024.

Figure 9: Analysis of government-issued circulating paper money and coins by the end of 2024

# Hong Kong Banknotes

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority held 14 seminars on Hong Kong banknote design and anti-counterfeiting features, attracting over 2,600 participants, including bank counter staff, retail store cashiers, and students, which helped enhance their knowledge and skills in identifying banknotes.

# Coin Collection Program

The coin collection scheme continues to be popular among the public. Details of the scheme are included in the “HKMA and Sustainable Development” chapter of the 2024 Sustainable Development Report.

# US dollar liquidity arrangements

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced enhancements to its US dollar liquidity arrangements, including shortening the settlement cycle from T+1 to T+0, effective May 24. This standing liquidity arrangement will provide backup liquidity for licensed banks when needed, particularly in light of the United States’ implementation of a shortened settlement cycle to T+1 starting May 28.

# Foreign exchange fund bills and bonds

The Foreign Exchange Fund Notes and Bonds Program continues to operate smoothly. As of the end of 2024, the nominal value of outstanding Foreign Exchange Fund notes and bonds amounted to approximately HKD 1,306.8 billion (Table 2).

Table 2: Unredeemed foreign exchange fund bills and bonds

# Monetary research

In 2024, the Hong Kong Centre for Monetary and Financial Research, under the Faculty of Finance, published 15 research papers addressing monetary and financial issues of strategic importance to Hong Kong and the region. The Centre also disseminated its research through five issues of an open-access electronic journal, reaching a global audience. Furthermore, the Centre released two issues of *Insights from Monetary Research*, offering the public high-level, non-technical overviews of its recent publications.

Besides research work, the research center organized a series of knowledge exchange activities to foster connections with various stakeholders. Within the year, it held 31 seminars or online seminars targeting local participants, exploring important monetary and financial research topics. On an international level, the business school and research center collaborated with academic institutions, central banks of various countries, and international financial institutions to host four international conferences and five seminars or round table discussions, promoting dialogue and exchange on a wide range of economic and financial matters.

These international activities include:

April 11th

Jointly organized with the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Hong Kong University of Science and Technology

zh:
# 銀行體系穩定

儘管面對宏觀經濟挑戰及地緣政治的不確定性，香港銀行體系在2024年維持穩健。金管局迅速採取措施支援本地中小型企業，並透過風險為本監管與應變規劃保障銀行體系穩定，另又提供監管指引及支持業界應對新生風險，以提升銀行業的運作穩健性與網絡防衛韌性。為鼓勵應用金融科技，金管局推出連串跨行業項目，包括生成式人工智能「沙盒」。

金管局推出《保障消費者防詐騙約章2.0》，以加強銀行消費者保障。我們又推出「智安存」協助存款人有效保護存款，以及有關銀行無抵押消費信貸產品的冷靜期以減低衝動及過度借貸的風險。此外，金管局向銀行提供有關在面向客戶的服務中應用生成式人工智能的指引，又就二手物業買賣交易提供多一種支付安排與業界緊密合作。金管局亦透過發出數碼資產相關活動的指引、優化「跨境理財通」業務試點，以及簡化銷售投資及保險產品程序，提升客戶體驗，並同時確保投資者保障。年內完成個人信貸資料服務全面過渡至「信資通」。

金管局在香港的打擊洗錢及恐怖分子資金籌集制度方面扮演重要角色。透過提高經由反訛騙及洗黑錢情報工作組交換情報的速度及數量，與2023年相比，情報主導的可疑交易報告增加303%，促使凍結或充公的犯罪得益增加34%。有關促進銀行分享訊息以協助偵測及防止金融罪行的法例修訂的諮詢得到廣泛支持。金管局在4月根據交易監察系統專題審查結果提供指引，以及在9月推出計劃促進業界應用人工智能監察可疑活動。金管局亦與銀行業及香港警務處合作，優化「可疑帳號警示」機制及加強宣傳工作，並就防範、偵測及制止授權支付詐騙向銀行發出指引。

香港在實施包括資本充足及披露等國際監管標準方面取得良好進展。香港存款保障委員會優化了存款保障計劃的多個範疇，以加強對存款人的保障。

為確保處置機制具公信力，金管局實施處置標準，規定銀行須更新與對手方的金融合約，減低處置中的提前終止風險。此外，金管局在制定銀行的首選處置策略、應對處置可行性障礙以確保有足夠財政資源及處置中的運作持續性，以及提升處置執行能力方面均取得顯著進展。

# 目標

金管局的目標之一是促進銀行體系的安全及穩定。要達致這個目標，實有賴建立及維持具高度應對能力且能為香港經濟提供所需關鍵金融服務的金融體系。

銀行可能因其營運方式，甚或在極端情況下因失序地倒閉而影響金融體系的穩定。作為監管當局，金融管理專員在保障金融穩定方面擔當重要角色，確保銀行有能力抵禦衝擊及應對危機，以最終有助防止出現倒閉。金融管理專員負責對銀行進行審慎監管，以及認可香港的持牌銀行、有限制牌照銀行及接受存款公司（統稱「認可機構」）。

香港的審慎監管制度並非為確保「零風險」而設。事實上，作為一個處置機制當局，金融管理專員力求確保一旦有認可機構不再可持續經營，能有秩序地處理其倒閉。為此，香港已設立金融機構處置機制，金融管理專員在該機制下為認可機構的處置機制當局。為落實香港的處置機制，我們有必要制定處置規則及政策標準、進行處置規劃以排除認可機構處置可行性的障礙，以及建立金管局處置瀕臨倒閉認可機構的運作能力。為有效執行上述工作，金管局採納與國際一致及協調的方法。

金融管理專員亦負責指定及監察某些金融市場基建。金管局監察金融市場基建的目的，是促進有關基建的整體安全及效率、減低系統性風險，以及提高透明度。提升金融市場基建面對金融危機的抗震能力，能保障香港的貨幣與金融體系，避免因金融市場基建運作中斷而影響其穩定。

# 2024年回顧

# 牌照事宜

年內金管局向一間在香港成立為法團的銀行及一間在香港以外成立為法團的銀行授予銀行牌照。金管局亦核准一間在香港以外的交易商經紀成為貨幣經紀。此外，年內金管局撤銷三間持牌銀行、一間有限制牌照銀行及一間接受存款公司的認可資格。

有關香港的認可機構及本地代表辦事處的更多資訊，請參閱分別載於第311至314頁及第320至323頁的附錄及表D至F。

# 檢討銀行三級制

在2024年，金管局完成有關簡化銀行三級制至二級制的公眾諮詢，回應者普遍支持簡化建議。經考慮所收到的意見，金管局就建議提出若干新的關鍵事項，以精簡過渡過程及減少對接受存款公司現有客戶的影響。

# 「虛擬銀行」易名

此外，金管局完成有關「虛擬銀行(Virtual Bank)」易名為「數字銀行(Digital Bank)」的公眾諮詢。易名建議得到廣泛支持，金管局遂於10月修訂法定指引《數字銀行的認可》，有關建議正式生效。

# 數字銀行的檢討

在2024年完成的另一項工作是全面檢討數字銀行，檢討報告已於8月發表。有關檢討顯示數字銀行發展至今已達到在香港引入數字銀行的三項政策目標，即推動金融科技與創新、提供新的客戶體驗，以及促進普及金融。在數字銀行和傳統銀行的多樣化發展下，金管局認為現時數字銀行牌照的數量合適，現階段沒有必要在市場上引入更多新的數字銀行參與者。10月發出的修訂指引《數字銀行的認可》放寬了數項對業界的限制，包括容許數字銀行經營零售銀行業務以外的銀行業務，以及在從客戶體驗與業務策略的角度而言屬合理的情況下設立實體分行，前提是數字銀行繼續主要透過數碼渠道提供銀行服務。

# 銀行牌照費的檢討

金管局於年內完成對牌照費的檢討，並於6月提高費用水平。

# 香港的公司遷冊制度

金管局就於香港引入公司遷冊制度向政府提供支援，包括協助修訂《銀行業條例》及其附屬法例以及其他與金管局有關的法例的立法程序。

# 監管工作概覽

年內金管局共進行174次非現場審查，涵蓋範圍甚廣，包括認可機構的CAMEL評估、企業管治及風險管理。為繼續加強認可機構的風險管治水平，金管局與認可機構董事局、獨立非執行董事或董事局轄下委員會共舉行36次會議，並與認可機構及其外聘核數師共舉行38次三方聯席會議。此外，金管局對認可機構的各項業務進行現場審查，包括信用、市場及流動性風險管理方面的管治與做法。

鑑於認可機構應用科技的情況越趨普及，業務操作風險及科技風險管理是另一個監管重點。金管局亦進一步加強對認可機構氣候風險管理的監管，以提高認可機構應對氣候變化的能力。金管局在全球經濟不明朗的環境下維持金融穩定及促進經濟穩健增長等方面的工作得到肯定，獲《亞洲銀行家》雜誌(The AsianBanker)評選為「亞太區最佳宏觀經濟監管機構」(BestMacroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific)。

助理總裁（銀行監理）朱立翹女士（中）代表金管局領取《亞洲銀行家》雜誌頒發的「亞太區最佳宏觀經濟監管機構獎項

在操守監管方面，金管局對認可機構的證券、投資產品、信託、保險及強制性公積金（強積金）相關業務，以及消費者保障事項進行現場審查，並以專題評估作為配合，以審視新的項目或被評估為屬較高風險的範疇。

表1載有金管局於2024年的監管工作概要。

表 1 監管工作概要

a. 聚焦於運作穩健性的額外監管工作包括一項金管局調查及認可機構進行自我評估以審視實施進度和識別需要加強的環節，以及就架構制定與做法在雙邊與業界層面進行廣泛的外展活動。
b. 此外，監管工作集中評估認可機構對特定信貸組合的審批和持續風險管理的策略與手法，例如對商用物業及中小型企業貸款。
c. 包括與認可機構舉行諮詢會議，以檢視其實施金管局《監管政策手冊》單元GS-1「氣候風險管理」的情況。

# 信用風險

# 信貸增長及資產質素

2024年貸款總額減少2.8%，2023年的跌幅為3.6%。表2列載各類貸款及墊款的增長情況。2024年內地相關貸款總額減少8.7%至38,590億港元（表3）。

鑑於利率仍然高企、部分內地房地產發展商的債務問題還未完全緩解，以及本地商業房地產市場疲弱，金管局在2024年繼續密切監察認可機構的資產質素及評估其信用風險管理手法。年內銀行體系的資產質素持續面對壓力，但風險形勢仍屬可控。銀行體系的特定分類貸款比率於2024年底為1.96%，高於2023年底的1.57%，而同期內地相關貸款的特定分類貸款比率則由2.58%下降至2.38%。

年內金管局進行專題評估，檢視認可機構的信用風險管理，當中重點包括對較易受影響行業的風險承擔、對私人銀行及財富管理客戶的有抵押貸款、無抵押零售貸款、對香港境外業務的信用風險的監察，以及對非銀行金融機構的風險承擔。

表 2 貸款及墊款的增長

表 3 內地相關貸款增長

# 紓緩銀行客戶的資金流壓力

# 支持本地中小企

中小企是香港經濟的重要基石，金管局一直密切關注它們獲取銀行融資的情況。自金管局與銀行業於2019年成立「銀行業中小企貸款協調機制」（中小企協調機制）以來，合共推出多輪中小企支援措施，包括「預先批核還息不還本」計劃，協助中小企渡過新冠疫情期間的困境。

在2024年，金管局與銀行業推出更多措施，支持經營情況因經濟轉型而仍然面對挑戰的中小企，並協助中小企持續發展和升級轉型。

# 新的中小企支持措施

金管局透過中小企協調機制於3月推出九項措施，協助中小企獲取銀行融資，以及支持其持續發展。

於3月公布的九項支持中小企措施

1. 不要求按時供款按揭客戶提前還款
2. 調整信貸額度給予客戶最少六個月過渡期

en:
# The banking system is stable.

Despite facing macroeconomic challenges and geopolitical uncertainties, the Hong Kong banking system maintained stability in 2024. The HKMA swiftly took measures to support local small and medium-sized enterprises, and ensured banking system stability through risk-based regulation and response planning. It also provided regulatory guidance and supported the industry in addressing emerging risks, thereby enhancing the operational resilience and network defense capabilities of the banking sector. To encourage the application of fintech, the HKMA launched a series of cross-industry initiatives, including the generative artificial intelligence "Sandbox."

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has launched the "Consumer Protection Against Fraud Charter 2.0" to strengthen consumer protection in banking. We have also introduced "SmartSafe Deposit" to help depositors effectively protect their deposits, as well as a cooling-off period for banks' unsecured consumer credit products to reduce the risks of impulsive and excessive borrowing. Additionally, the HKMA has provided guidelines for the application of generative artificial intelligence in customer-facing services and introduced an additional payment arrangement for second-hand property transactions, collaborating closely with the industry. The HKMA has also enhanced customer experience and ensured investor protection by issuing guidelines on digital asset-related activities, optimising the Cross-Border Wealth Management Link pilot program, and simplifying procedures for selling investment and insurance products. The full transition of personal credit information services to "CreditLink" will be completed within the year.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) plays a vital role in Hong Kong's anti-money laundering and counter-terrorism financing regime. By increasing the speed and volume of information sharing through the Anti-Fraud and Money Laundering Intelligence Task Force, intelligence-led suspicious transaction reports increased by 303% compared to 2023, leading to a 34% increase in criminal proceeds that were frozen or confiscated. The consultation on legal revisions to promote information sharing among banks to assist in detecting and preventing financial crimes received widespread support. In April, the HKMA provided guidance based on the results of a thematic review of the transaction monitoring system, and in September launched a program to promote the industry's application of artificial intelligence in monitoring suspicious activities. The HKMA also collaborated with the banking sector and the Hong Kong Police Force to optimize the "Suspicious Account Alert" mechanism and enhance publicity efforts, and issued guidelines to banks on preventing, detecting, and stopping authorized payment fraud.

Hong Kong has made good progress in implementing international regulatory standards, including capital adequacy and disclosure. The Hong Kong Deposit Protection Corporation has optimized various aspects of the deposit protection scheme to enhance protection for depositors.

To ensure the credibility of the resolution mechanism, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has implemented resolution standards, requiring banks to update financial contracts with counterparties to reduce the risk of early termination during resolution. In addition, the HKMA has made significant progress in developing banks' preferred resolution strategies, addressing resolution feasibility obstacles to ensure adequate financial resources and operational continuity during resolution, as well as enhancing resolution execution capabilities.

# Objective

One of the HKMA’s objectives is to promote the safety and stability of the banking system. Achieving this goal requires establishing and maintaining a financial system that is highly resilient and capable of providing essential financial services for the Hong Kong economy.

Banks may affect the stability of the financial system due to their operating methods, or even collapse in a disorderly manner under extreme circumstances. As a regulatory authority, the Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau plays an important role in safeguarding financial stability, ensuring banks have the ability to withstand shocks and respond to crises, ultimately helping to prevent collapses. The Financial Services and the Treasury Bureau is responsible for prudentially supervising banks, and licensing banks, restricted licence banks and deposit-taking companies in Hong Kong (collectively known as “licensed institutions”).

Hong Kong’s prudential regulatory system is not designed to ensure "zero risk." In fact, as a resolution authority, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) aims to ensure that if an authorized institution becomes unsustainable, its failure can be handled in an orderly manner. To this end, Hong Kong has established a financial institution resolution mechanism, under which the HKMA serves as the resolution authority for authorized institutions. To implement Hong Kong’s resolution mechanism, it is necessary to establish resolution rules and policy standards, conduct resolution planning to remove obstacles to the resolvability of authorized institutions, and build the HKMA’s operational capacity to resolve failing authorized institutions. To effectively carry out the above tasks, the HKMA adopts methods that are consistent and coordinated with international standards.

Financial management officers are also responsible for designating and supervising certain financial market infrastructure. The HKMA’s supervision of financial market infrastructure aims to promote the overall safety and efficiency of that infrastructure, reduce systemic risk, and enhance transparency. Enhancing the resilience of financial market infrastructure to financial crises can safeguard Hong Kong’s monetary and financial system and prevent disruptions in its operation from affecting its stability.

# 2024 Year in Review

# License matters

During the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) granted banking licenses to one bank incorporated as a corporation in Hong Kong and one bank incorporated as a corporation outside Hong Kong. The HKMA also approved a dealer broker established outside Hong Kong to become a money broker. In addition, during the year, the HKMA revoked the authorization of three licensed banks, one restricted license bank, and one deposit-taking company.

For more information about the accredited institutions and local representative offices in Hong Kong, please refer to the appendices and tables D to F on pages 311 to 314 and 320 to 323, respectively.

# Reviewing the Three-Tier System for Banks

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) completed public consultations on simplifying the banking system from a three-tier to a two-tier structure. Respondents generally supported the simplification. After considering the feedback received, the HKMA proposed several new key matters to streamline the transition process and reduce the impact on existing customers of deposit-taking companies.

# Renaming "Virtual Bank"

此外，金管局完成有關“虛擬銀行(Virtual Bank)”易名為“數字銀行(Digital Bank)”的公眾諮詢。易名建議得到廣泛支持，金管局遂於10月修訂法定指引《數字銀行的認可》，有關建議正式生效。

# Review of digital banks

Another piece of work completed in 2024 was a comprehensive review of virtual banks, with the review report published in August. The review indicated that the development of virtual banks has to date achieved the three policy objectives of introducing virtual banks in Hong Kong: promoting financial technology and innovation, providing new customer experiences, and fostering financial inclusion. With the diversified development of virtual banks and traditional banks, the HKMA considers that the current number of virtual bank licenses is appropriate and there is no need at this stage to introduce more new participants into the market. The revised Guideline on Authorization of Virtual Banks issued in October relaxed a number of restrictions on the industry, including allowing virtual banks to conduct banking business beyond retail banking, and to establish physical branches where it is reasonable from the perspective of customer experience and business strategy, provided that virtual banks continue to primarily provide banking services through digital channels.

# Review of bank license fees

The Monetary Authority completed a review of license fees within the year and raised the fee levels in June.

# Hong Kong Company Transfer Registration System

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority provides support to the government in introducing the company deregistration system in Hong Kong, including assisting in the legislative process of amending the Banking Ordinance and its subsidiary legislation, as well as other legislation related to the Hong Kong Monetary Authority.

# Overview of Supervisory Work

This year, the Monetary Authority conducted a total of 174 off-site inspections, covering a wide range of areas including the CAMEL assessment of authorized institutions, corporate governance, and risk management. To further enhance the risk management standards of authorized institutions, the Monetary Authority held 36 meetings with the boards of authorized institutions, independent non-executive directors, or committees under the boards, and 38 tripartite meetings with authorized institutions and their external auditors. In addition, the Monetary Authority carried out on-site reviews of various operations of authorized institutions, including governance and practices related to credit, market, and liquidity risk management.

Given the increasing prevalence of technology adoption by authorized institutions, operational risk and technology risk management have become another regulatory focus. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has also further strengthened its supervision of authorized institutions’ climate risk management to enhance their capacity to respond to climate change. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s work in maintaining financial stability and promoting robust economic growth in an uncertain global economic environment has been recognized, to effect being named “Best Macroeconomic Regulator in Asia Pacific” by The AsianBanker magazine.

Ms. Zhu Liqiao, Assistant Governor (Banking Supervision) (center) represented the HKMA in receiving the "Best Macroeconomic Regulatory Authority in Asia-Pacific" award presented by The Asian Banker magazine.

In terms of conduct supervision, the Authority oversees on-site inspections of authorized institutions' securities, investment products, trusts, insurance, and mandatory Provident Fund (MPF) related activities, as well as consumer protection matters. It also conducts thematic assessments to review new items or areas assessed as higher risk.

Table 1 outlines the Financial Supervisory Commission’s regulatory work summary for 2024.

Table 1: Overview of Regulatory Work

a. Additional regulatory work focused on operational soundness includes an investigation by the Monetary Authority and self-assessment by authorized institutions to review implementation progress and identify areas requiring improvement, as well as conducting extensive outreach activities at the bilateral and industry levels regarding the framework and practices.  
b. In addition, regulatory work focuses on assessing authorized institutions' approval processes and strategies and methods for continuous risk management of specific credit portfolios, such as commercial property and SME loans.  
c. This includes holding consultation meetings with authorized institutions to review their implementation of the Monetary Authority's "Regulatory Policy Manual" section GS-1 "Climate Risk Management."

# Credit risk

# Loan growth and asset quality

The total loan amount decreased by 2.8% in 2024, compared to a decline of 3.6% in 2023. Table 2 shows the growth of various types of loans and advances. The total amount of related loans in Hong Kong decreased by 8.7% to 38,590 billion HK dollars in 2024 (Table 3).

In view of persistently high interest rates, unresolved debt issues among some mainland property developers, and a weak local commercial real estate market, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continued to closely monitor the asset quality of authorized institutions and assess their credit risk management approaches in 2024. Throughout the year, the banking system's asset quality continued to face pressure, but the risk situation remained manageable. The specific classification loan ratio for the banking system stood at 1.96% at the end of 2024, up from 1.57% at the end of 2023, while the specific classification loan ratio for mainland-related loans decreased from 2.58% to 2.38% during the same period.

In the course of the year, the HKMA conducted a thematic review to examine the credit risk management practices of authorized institutions, focusing on areas including risk exposure to more vulnerable industries, secured loans and unsecured retail loans extended to private banks and wealth management clients, monitoring of credit risk related to operations outside Hong Kong, as well as risk exposure to non-bank financial institutions.

Table 2: Growth of Loans and Advances

Table 3 Mainland related loan growth

# Alleviate the pressure on cash flow for bank customers

# Support Local SMEs

Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) are an important cornerstone of Hong Kong's economy, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has been closely monitoring their access to bank financing. Since the HKMA and the banking sector established the "Banking Sector SME Loan Coordination Mechanism" (SME Coordination Mechanism) in 2019, multiple rounds of SME support measures have been introduced, including the "Pre-Approved Interest-Only Repayment" Scheme, to help SMEs overcome difficulties during the pandemic.

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, together with the banking sector, introduced more measures to support small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) that continue to face challenges due to economic transformation, and to assist SMEs in sustaining their development and upgrading their operations.

# New support measures for SMEs

The Monetary Authority introduced nine measures through its SME Coordination Mechanism in March to assist SMEs in accessing bank financing and support their sustained development.

Nine support measures for small and medium-sized enterprises announced in March

1. Do not require mortgage customers to repay early if they are unable to make timely payments  
2. Adjust credit limits and provide customers with at least a six-month transition period

zh:
# 香港的國際金融中心地位

金管局於2024年在加強香港作為具全球競爭力的國際金融中心的地位方面取得重要進展。

金管局與內地及香港有關當局合作，推出一系列措施，共同深化及擴展香港與內地金融市場的互聯互通，包括優化「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」；擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排及「北向互換通」的合資格抵押品範圍；優化「北向互換通」；以及優化一級流動性提供行安排。這些措施有助強化香港的門戶角色，並鞏固其作為全球離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位

金管局在鞏固香港金融平台的競爭力方面亦取得良好進展，涵蓋債券發行、資產及財富管理、綠色和可持續金融，以及企業財資中心等範疇。為宣傳香港的金融服務，金管局加強面向海外及內地持份者的市場推廣工作，讓大家充分認識香港金融體系的穩健及其帶來的機遇。第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」及多項其他盛事成功舉辦，不僅有助提升香港作為主要國際金融中心的形象，更製造正面的漣漪效應。金管局積極參與多個國際及區內的央行及監管組織，繼續對維持金融穩定及促進金融市場發展的全球工作作出貢獻。

金管局在「金融科技2025」 策略的各個範疇均取得顯著進展，包括央行數碼貨幣及數據基建。

快速支付系統「轉數快」的登記數目及交易量繼續穩步增長，於2024年底達到1,580萬個登記，全年平均每日處理港元即時交易增至165萬宗。金管局正與中國人民銀行緊密合作，推動落實香港「轉數快」與內地網上支付跨行清算系統互聯，實現跨境支付。

# 概覽

在2024年，金管局繼續致力提升香港作為國際金融中心的競爭力。

金管局擴展及優化香港與內地間的互聯互通機制，有助鞏固香港作為內地與國際金融市場間的橋樑角色。年內，多項有關「粵港澳大灣區跨境理財通」（「跨境理財通」）的優化措施出台，便利粵港澳大灣區（大灣區）個人投資者進行跨境投資。於2月，金管局將中華人民共和國財政部（國家財政部）發行的在岸國債和內地政策性銀行發行的政策性金融債納入人民幣流動資金安排的合資格抵押品名單。於7月，兩地相關部門公布進一步支持境外投資者使用通過「債券通」持有的在岸債券作為「北向互換通」交易的履約抵押品，並於2025年1月實施。此外，「北向互換通」於年內進行優化，增加投資者在對沖策略和管理投資組合方面的靈活性及效率。

在2024年，香港的離岸人民幣業務穩健增長。金管局推出一級流動性提供行安排的優化措施，包括增加提供行數目及擴大安排規模。於年底前，香港人民幣即時支付結算系統的夜間跨境服務能力提升，以更好應付全球各地對跨境人民幣支付的需要。

金管局推出大灣區金融合作下的多項利民便商措施，包括促進企業跨境融資的跨境徵信互通業務試點，以及便利香港居民在大灣區置業的跨境匯款支付安排。

金管局繼續致力提升香港整體金融平台的競爭力。具體而言，為增強香港作為首選基金管理中心及家族辦公室業務樞紐的吸引力，金管局與政府及金融業緊密合作，締造更便利的稅務及監管環境。此外，金管局透過Evergreen項目發行第二批代幣化債券，並推出「EvergreenHub」一站式數碼債券知識庫和「數碼債券資助計劃」，繼續推動香港債券市場創新。於10月，金管局公布「可持續金融行動計劃」，訂明進一步鞏固香港作為區內綠色和可持續金融樞紐的具體目標。

另一方面，金管局繼續加強市場拓展工作，向海外及內地持份者介紹香港的金融服務。金管局在11月舉辦第三屆「國際金融領袖投資峰會」。峰會為期三日，主題為「在變局中前航」，雲集全球各地金融業界翹楚分享各自獨到的觀點。峰會先由國務院副總理何立峰先生作開幕主題演講，接着是三間內地金融監管機構的分享環節，以及由國際金融領袖參與的專題討論。峰會共匯聚350多位來自超過120間國際金融機構的領袖參與，充分體現國際金融界對香港的支持和信心。

年內金管局亦舉辦各項其他研討會及會議，包括：

- 於9月與迪拜金融服務管理局合辦聯合氣候金融會議；
- 於10月與全球風險管理專業人士協會合辦第15屆全球風險論壇；
- 於10月亦與國際結算銀行合辦國際金融研討會；及
- 於12月舉辦金融穩定理事會全體會議，是自2016年以來首次在亞洲舉行的同類會議，匯聚超過50個國家財政金融機關及12個國際標準制定機構的領袖和高級官員。

年內金管局亦積極加強與其他地區的雙邊聯繫。於12月，金管局分別與阿拉伯聯合酋長國中央銀行（阿聯酋央行）及沙特中央銀行（沙特央行）在香港舉行雙邊會議，促進中東與亞洲地區之間的投資及金融市場聯繫。金管局與阿聯酋央行簽署諒解備忘錄，建立兩地債務資本市場基建的互聯互通，並促進跨境債務證券發行及投資活動。在此之前，金管局於10月訪問卡塔爾多哈，加強兩地金融服務領域的合作。

此外，金管局於12月舉行第七次香港與瑞士金融合作對話，討論內容涵蓋區內及本地的前景與政策挑戰，以及可持續金融、金融科技與市場互聯互通領域的最新發展及潛在合作空間。

金管局分別於1月及5月訪問泰國和馬來西亞，與中央銀行、金融機構和企業會面，推廣香港作為國際金融中心的地位，並進一步加強雙邊金融聯繫和合作。重點領域之一是推廣使用人民幣和本地貨幣作跨境投資和貿易結算，以及香港的競爭優勢。

在國際層面，金管局積極參與中央銀行領域的事務，並繼續在多個區內及國際委員會擔當領導角色。金管局現為巴塞爾銀行監管委員會（巴塞爾委員會）轄下政策及標準小組和金融穩定理事會轄下亞洲區域諮詢小組的聯席主席，另又擔任金融穩定理事會轄下金融創新網絡聯席主席（至2024年7月止）。金管局亦為國際結算銀行轄下主要新興市場經濟體行長會議和金融穩定理事會轄下加密資產框架同業評審小組的主席。在2018至2024年間，金管局一直連任東亞及太平洋地區中央銀行會議(EMEAP)轄下金融市場工作小組主席。

金管局金融科技促進辦公室與各銀行部門繼續實施「金融科技2025」策略，促進業界廣泛採用金融科技，並提升香港作為亞洲金融科技樞紐的地位。年內推行的主要措施包括：

- 進一步推動銀行在五個主要範疇的金融科技應用，包括財富科技、保險科技、綠色科技、人工智能及分布式分類帳技術；
- 推動央行數碼貨幣的工作，以了解其效益及潛在的應用場景，包括：
    - 推進「多種央行數碼貨幣跨境網絡」(mBridge)項目，以改善跨境支付；
    - 進一步研究在香港發行「數碼港元」(e-HKD)的可行性；及
    - 開始探索以央行數碼貨幣支持香港代幣化市場的發展；
- 透過「商業數據通」便利中小企借貸；
- 加強跨境金融科技合作；及
- 推動更廣泛使用快速支付系統「轉數快」。

「轉數快」的使用在2024年繼續增加，登記數目與交易量在過去六年穩步上升。截至2024年底，「轉數快」登記數目增至1,580萬個，全年每日平均交易宗數較上年上升33%。除個人對個人支付及商業支付穩步增長外，透過「轉數快」繳付政府帳單、支付予商戶及為儲值支付工具電子錢包或銀行帳戶增值持續增加，是帶動「轉數快」交易量持續增長的主要原因。

為確保本地零售支付業的安全及效率，金管局根據《支付系統及儲值支付工具條例》（《支付條例》）監察六個指定零售支付系統，並監管15項持牌儲值支付工具（其中四項由持牌銀行發行）。年內金管局繼續與業界緊密合作，因應詐騙風險上升加強管控措施及保障消費者。

財經事務及庫務局與金管局就在香港實施穩定幣發行人監管制度的立法建議，於2月完成為期兩個月的公眾諮詢後，於7月聯合發表諮詢總結，並於12月將《穩定幣條例草案》提交立法會審議。為更了解穩定幣發行人的業務模式，並制定適切的監管制度，金管局亦推出穩定幣發行人「沙盒」，並於7月公布三間進入「沙盒」的參與機構。與此同時，金管局繼續積極參與國際組織在數碼資產相關課題（包括穩定幣及代幣化）的工作，確保相關監管框架符合國際標準及最佳做法。

# 金管局於2024年就加強香港國際金融中心競爭力的措施一覽

深化香港與內地金融市場互聯互通鞏固香港作為離岸人民幣業務樞紐的地位及加強大灣區內的聯繫

- 優化「跨境理財通」及「北向互換通」
- 擴大金管局人民幣流動資金安排和「北向互換通」的合資格抵押品範圍，納入國家財政部和內地政策性銀行發行的在岸人民幣債券
- 優化一級流動性提供行安排
- 提升香港的人民幣即時支付結算系統的夜間跨境服務能力，以更好應付全球各地對跨境人民幣支付的需要
- 為深圳市政府、廣東省政府及海南省政府在香港發行點心債提供支持
- 通過跨境徵信互通合作，便利企業跨境融資
- 實施大灣區置業的跨境匯款便利化措施
- 加深內地相關機構與香港金融業的交流及溝通，開拓商機

# 加強與全球各地的聯繫

- 舉辦連串國際盛事：「國際金融領袖投資峰會」、金融穩定理事會全體會議，以及與國際結算銀行合辦研討會
- 加強市場拓展工作，向海外及內地持份者推廣香港的金融服務，並奠下與中東及東南亞國家聯盟（東盟）地區合作的堅實基礎
- 積極參與國際及區內的央行及監管組織

# 提升金融平台競爭力

- 透過Evergreen項目推動債券市場創新，包括協助政府發行全球首批多幣種數碼債券啟動一站式數碼債券知識庫「EvergreenHub ，並且推出「數碼債券資助計劃

en:
# Hong Kong’s position as a global financial hub.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority made significant progress in 2024 in strengthening Hong Kong’s position as a globally competitive international financial centre.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is collaborating with mainland and Hong Kong authorities to launch a series of measures, jointly deepening and expanding the mutual connectivity between Hong Kong and mainland financial markets, including enhancements to the “Greater Bay Area Cross-Border Wealth Management Connect”; expanding the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s RMB liquidity facility arrangement and the eligible collateral range for “Inward Market Access”; optimising “Inward Market Access”; and enhancements to the Tier 1 liquidity providing bank arrangement. These measures will help strengthen Hong Kong’s hub role and consolidate its position as a global offshore RMB business hub.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has also made solid progress in strengthening Hong Kong's competitiveness as a financial hub, covering areas such as bond issuance, asset and wealth management, green and sustainable finance, and corporate treasury centers. To promote Hong Kong's financial services, the HKMA has enhanced its marketing efforts targeting overseas and mainland stakeholders, helping them fully understand the robustness of Hong Kong's financial system and the opportunities it brings. The successful holding of the third “International Financial Leaders Investment Summit” and other major events not only helped enhance Hong Kong's image as a major international financial center but also created a positive ripple effect. The HKMA actively participates in various international and regional central banks and regulatory organizations, continuing to contribute to global efforts in maintaining financial stability and promoting financial market development.

The Financial Supervisory Agency has made significant progress in all areas of the "FinTech 2025" strategy, including central bank digital currency and data infrastructure.

The registration numbers and transaction volume of the Quick Pay system continue to grow steadily, reaching 15.8 million registrations by the end of 2024, with the average daily processing of HKD instant transactions increasing to 1.65 million. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority is working closely with the People's Bank of China to promote the connection between Hong Kong's Quick Pay and the mainland's cross-bank online payment clearing system, enabling cross-border payments.

# Overview

In 2024, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority will continue to dedicate itself to enhancing Hong Kong's competitiveness as an international financial center.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority's expansion and optimization of the connectivity mechanism between Hong Kong and the mainland help consolidate Hong Kong's role as a bridge between the mainland and international financial markets. This year, several optimization measures related to the "Cross-border Financial Services Facilitation Scheme for the Greater Bay Area" ("Cross-border Financial Services Facilitation Scheme") were introduced, facilitating cross-border investments for individual investors in the Greater Bay Area (GBA). In February, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority included onshore Chinese government bonds issued by the Ministry of Finance of the People's Republic of China (the National Ministry of Finance) and policy financial bonds issued by mainland policy banks in the list of eligible collateral under the RMB liquidity arrangement. In July, relevant authorities from both sides announced further support for overseas investors to use onshore bonds held through the "Bond Connect" as collateral for transactions under the "Northbound Swap Facility," which will be implemented in January 2025. In addition, the "Northbound Swap Facility" was optimized during the year, enhancing investors' flexibility and efficiency in hedging strategies and managing investment portfolios.

In 2024, Hong Kong's offshore RMB business experienced steady growth. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority introduced optimized measures for the primary liquidity provider arrangement, including increasing the number of participating banks and expanding the scale of the arrangement. By the end of the year, the overnight cross-border service capacity of Hong Kong's RMB real-time payment settlement system was enhanced to better meet the global demand for cross-border RMB payments.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority has introduced a series of measures benefiting the public and facilitating business under the Greater Bay Area financial cooperation framework, including a pilot program for cross-border credit information interoperability to promote corporate cross-border financing, as well as cross-border remittance arrangements to facilitate property purchases by Hong Kong residents in the Greater Bay Area.
